(Lockwood, to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, 2009) | source =<ref name="telegraph" /> | width =25% | align =right }} '''''Six-Legged Soldiers: Using Insects as Weapons of War''''' is a [[nonfiction]] scientific warfare book written by award-winning author and [[University of Wyoming]] professor, [[Jeffrey A. Lockwood]]. Published in 2008 by [[Oxford University Press]], the book explores the history of [[bioterrorism]], [[entomological warfare]], [[biological warfare]], and the prevention of [[agro-terrorism]] from the earliest times to modern threats.<ref name="timesonline" /> Lockwood, an entomologist, preceded this book with ''Ethical issues in biological control'' (1997) and ''Locust: The devastating rise and mysterious disappearance of the insect that shaped the American frontier'' (2004), among others.
==Summary== ''Six-Legged Soldiers'' gives detailed examples of entomological warfare: using buckets of scorpions during a fortress siege, [[catapult]]ing [[beehive]]s ("bee bombs") across a castle wall, civilians as human [[human subject research|guinea pigs]] in an effort to weaponize the [[Bubonic Plague|plague]], bombarding civilians from the air with infection-bearing insects, and [[assassin bug]]s placed on prisoners to eat away their flesh.<ref name="timesonline" /><ref name="Publishers">{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6587574.html |title=Nonfiction Reviews |date=August 18, 2008 |work=Six-Legged Soldiers: Using Insects as Weapons of War Jeffrey A. Lockwood. Oxford Univ., $27.95 |publisher=[[Publishers Weekly]] |accessdate=2009-01-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107173633/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6587574.html |archivedate=January 7, 2009 }}</ref> Lockwood also describes a domestic [[ecoterrorism]] example with the 1989 threat to release the [[Medfly]] (''Ceratitis capitata'') within California's crop belt.<ref name="oupcanada">{{cite web|url=http://www.oupcanada.com/catalog/9780195333053.html|title=Six-Legged Soldiers|publisher=oupcanada.com|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref> The last chapter highlights western nations' vulnerability to [[terrorist attack]]s.<ref name="Nature ">{{cite journal|last=Linthicum|first=Kenneth J. |date=November 5, 2008|title=Insects of war, terror and torture|journal=Nature |publisher=Nature Publishing Group|volume=456|pages=36â€“37|issn=0028-0836|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v456/n7218/full/456036a.html|doi=10.1038/456036a|issue=7218}}</ref>
Interviewed about the book by [[BBC Radio 4]]'s [[Today programme]], the author describes how a [[terrorist]] with a suitcase could bring diseases into a country. "I think a small terrorist cell could very easily develop an insect-based weapon."<ref name="telegraph">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/wildlife/4123782/Terrorists-could-use-insect-based-biological-weapon.html|title=Terrorists could use 'insect-based' biological weapon |last=Adams |first=Stephen |date=5 Jan 2009|publisher=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref>
==Criticism== In its January 2009 review, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' criticised the book as being "scarcely scholarly" for its mixed collection of myth, legend and historical facts.<ref name="timesonline">{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/non-fiction/article5424088.ece|title=Six-legged Soldiers: Using Insects as Weapons of War by Jeffrey A Lockwood |last=Hastings |first=Max |date=January 4, 2009|publisher=timesonline.co.uk|accessdate=2009-01-05}}</ref>
